pages.text: Seeds don't drop from grass. You'll need to find crops growing infrequently in oases or in villages.$(br2)A balanced diet pays off in the form of increased strength and resistance.$(br2)Loading up on individual food groups increases your max health.

Most food rots in 8 days; pan-cooked dishes last longer.$(br2)Food rots half as fast in a larder, 1/10 as fast in an esky, 1/100 in an icebox, and not at all in a freezer.$(br2)Craft two stacks of food together to average out their rot levels.
Simple foods don't restore much hunger; pan-cooked dishes restore a lot more.$(br2)When cooking in a wok, ingredients are ready when their circle fills and they start to change colour.

Prep ingredients on a cutting board or in a mortar before cooking to reduce the chance of them being undercooked.$(br2)Dishes seasoned with salt, sugar, or other seasonings restore more hunger than plain dishes.$(br2)Some ingredients can add potion effects to pan-cooked meals.

Flour can be cooked directly to bread, or you can make it into dough first to double your yield.$(br2)Food cooked in a furnace often doesn't stack on its own, halting progress after the first. Extract products with a hopper to keep the output slot clear.

Mills and jars need precise ratios of ingredients to work.$(br2)Mills will output items into an adjacent inventory, if there is one.$(br2)You can get fluids out of a mill with a bottle, bucket, spice bottle, or faucet.
